titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Solange Clésinger-Sand Papers
titlestmt.author: by Michael L. Forstrom

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 04:24

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Collection contains correspondence, writings, and other papers documenting the life and work of Solange Clésinger-Sand. Correspondence consists of letters to and from Clésinger-Sand and third-party letters between family and others. Notable correspondents include the following friends, family, and family friends: Éduoard Bourdet, Alphonse Guérin, Amélie Grille de Beuzelin, Maurice Sand, Charles Poncy, Samuel Rocheblave, and Jules Troubat. Writings by Clésinger-Sand include complete manuscripts for the early "Les roses et une fauvette..." (1834), "Histoirettes pour les toute petits," and a travelogue entitled "Une visite à Charon", in addition to a number of drafts for incomplete projects, including a play ("Sélim"), a theatrical adaptation of the novel L'Uscoque by George Sand, and a novel ("Thora"). Other materials include artwork, clippings, financial and legal records, notebooks, photographs, and papers relating to property ("Villa Malgrétout") purchased by Clésinger-Sand. Photographs include portraits of Clésinger-Sand, her husband, sculptor Jean Baptiste Clésinger, and others.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Amazones on the Edith and Richard French Fund, 2009, and on the Frederick W. Hilles Fund, 2012.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Solange Clésinger-Sand Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Solange Clésinger-Sand Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

bioghist.head: Solange Clésinger-Sand (1828-1899)
bioghist.p: Solange Clésinger-Sand, daughter of prolific 19th century French author George Sand and Casimir Dudevant. Studied piano with Frédéric Chopin during Chopin's summer sojourns at the Sand estate in Nohant from the late 1830s to mid 1840s. Married sculptor Jean-Baptiste (Auguste) Clésinger in 1847. Author of two published novels, Jacques Bruneau (1870) and Carl Robert (1887). Samuel Rocheblave, biographer of George Sand, compiled the correspondence between Solange and her mother as George Sand et sa fille d'après leur correspondance inédite (1905).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Solange Clésinger-Sand papers contain correspondence, writings, and other papers. Correspondence consists of letters to and from Solange Clésinger-Sand and third-party letters between family members and others. Notable correspondents with Clésinger-Sand include the following friends, family, and family friends: Nazli and Wacyf Azmy, Éduoard Bourdet, General Cantilli, Alphonse Guérin, Amélie Grille de Beuzelin, Maurice Sand, Charles Poncy, Samuel Rocheblave, and Jules Troubat. Writings include complete manuscripts for the early "Les roses et une fauvette..." (1834), "Histoirettes pour les toute petits," and a travelogue entitled "Une visite à Charon", in addition to a number of drafts for incomplete projects, including the play "Sélim," a theatrical adaptation of L'Uscoque , a novel by George Sand, entitled "Orio Soranzo," and a novel, [On Thora]. Writings also include manuscript notes and fragments. Other materials include artwork, clippings, financial and legal records, notebooks, photographs, and papers relating to a property in Cannes, named Villa Malgrétout, purchased by Clésinger-Sand in 1869. Photographs include portraits of Clésinger-Sand, Alfieri di Sostegno, Jean-Baptiste (Auguste) Clésinger, Charles Poncy, and Fernand de Préaulx.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence, 1849-1899. II. Writings, 1834-1862. III. Other Material, 1852-1952.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries for General Correspondence and Third-Party Correspondence. Arranged alphabetically by correspondent within subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, Correspondence, contains letters to and from Solange Clésinger-Sand and third-party correspondence. Notable correspondents with Clésinger-Sand include the following friends, family, and family friends: Nazli and Wacyf Azmy, Éduoard Bourdet, General Cantilli, Alphonse Guérin, Amélie Grille de Beuzelin, Maurice Sand, Charles Poncy, Samuel Rocheblave, and Jules Troubat. In addition, copies of correspondence between Clésinger-Sand and philosopher Pierre Lanfrey can be found in Series II. Writings, "Declaration perdue!" Outgoing letters from Clésinger-Sand to others are mentioned in folder notes.
Third-Party Correspondence consists chiefly of letters between family members and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Other Material, contains artwork, clippings, financial and legal records, notebooks, photographs, and papers relating to a property in Cannes purchased by Clésinger-Sand in 1869.

Photographs include studio portraits, with carte-de-visites and cabinet cards, and images of artwork and interiors of the Sand estate in Nohant, France. Portraits include Solange Clésinger-Sand, Alfieri di Sostegno, Jean-Baptiste (Auguste) Clésinger, Charles Poncy, Fernand de Préaulx, and others. Other photographs include an image of Auguste Clésinger's celebrated "Femme piquée par un serpent" [Woman bitten by a serpent] (1847) housed at the Musée d'Orsay.
